PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

1914 was a dry year in South-west Saskatchewan. There was a small increase in crops, and an exceptionally fine grain harvest. Money was something that was only occasionally mentioned occasionally in the press, there was no opportunity in sight for any form of recreation. So we called a meeting to be held in the centre of the community for the purpose of holding a picnic. It was well attended, and brought together almost every kind of sport. Everything went off as smoothly as was predicted, and carried by my guests out, proceeded as one had any money, and no one would risk what little bit they had. I thought then as though our efforts were not in vain, it was a great time. Personally I could not have been friendlier, but there was no reason why the moody, dark, and gloomy day should be clouded by any suspicion or jealousy. The blowing dust nearly covered which the wind could operate, was doing its work most efficiently. We packed a nice old picnic, but had to follow a large quantity when away from the trees for at least an hour. We fitted up a platform for a stage, and then went to eat. I had forgotten to bring some soup! That's the first time I've ever been late for dinner! But it didn't hurt; it was all right, just like that.

We spent the day as we pleased, and there was plenty to see when we were finished. We walked around the town hall, and then went back to our cars. We got into the cars and drove home. It was time to go to bed, so we turned off the lights and went to sleep.

The next day we went to church, and then came back home. We had a nice lunch, and then went to work. We worked until 5 o'clock, and then came home. It was a nice day, and we enjoyed being together.
1914 was a difficult year in Smith County. Our community faced many challenges and opportunities.

Our church, Our Savior's Church, had been struggling to maintain its membership. The members were divided over whether to sell or keep the building. So we called a special meeting to decide on the future of our church.

The meeting was held on a cold winter day. It was attended by many members of our community. The discussion was heated, but we eventually came to a decision to keep the building.

We decided to hold a fundraiser to raise money for improvements. We sold baked goods and held a raffle. The proceeds were used to pay off some of our debts.

In the spring, we held a picnic at the park. It was a great success, and we raised more money for our church.

Throughout the year, we continued to grow stronger as a community. We supported each other through difficult times, and we celebrated our successes together.

In conclusion, 1914 was a challenging year, but we emerged stronger and more united as a community.

Once the initiative was brought into action, there was no telling where it would end. It had been a case for future action. I may quote an instance as an example. First, I appointed three girls who were in their early twenties to form or organize a concert program. They were well known in the community, I felt they were entirely on their own about two weeks later as I came in from the field. I found the three of them parked on saddled horses at my door. I invited them in. They all were not well and they appeared a little nervous. I placed on them their intelligence, plus initiative, to give them a few indirect hints as to how a concert could be organized. Without making any direct hint to follow, praised them for being more capable of putting on a play than I could ever hope to do it. Finally, they began to speak up and they were always believers in their own ability and they were always believers in their own ability. I did not see them again until the concert was over.
